questions.text: Which of the following best describes a balanced diet?

options.label: A
options.text: A diet containing micronutrients forms the bulk of the food.

options.label: B
options.text: A diet consisting of 70% carbohydrates, 10% proteins, and 20% fats.

options.label: C
options.text: A diet adhered to dietary goals focused on high protein and vitamin intake.

options.label: D
options.text: A diet consisting of 150 gm/day of cereals, 40 gm/day of pulses and 10 gm/day of fat.

questions.correct_answer: B. A diet consisting of 70% carbohydrates, 10% proteins, and 20% fats.
questions.explanation:
Macronutrients

Micronutrients
  • Form the main bulk of the food (Option A)
  • Proportion of total energy intake (Option B):
    • Protein: 10-15%, 4 kcal/ gram
    • Carbohydrates: 50-80%, 4 kcal/gram
    • Fats: 15-30%, 9 kcal/gram
  • Required in small amounts (Option C)
  • Consists of vitamins and minerals.
  • Major minerals: Magnesium, Trace elements, Iron, Iodine, Zinc, Sodium, Potassium, Calcium.

Food item

Man (sedentary)

Female (sedentary)

Cereals

460 gm/day

410 gm/day

Pulses

40 gm

40 gm

Leafy vegetables

40 gm

100 gm

150 ml

100 ml

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension visits your clinic. During the consultation, you advise the patient to adopt a diet that reduces fat and salt intake. What type of diet is being recommended to this patient?
A 23-year-old male reports that his diet has been low in protein. Which of the following amino acids cannot be synthesised in the body and must be obtained from the diet?
questions.explanation:
1. Essential AA
(Option B)
  • Not synthesised in the body, it must obtained from the diet
  • Total 9: Phenylalanine, Valine, Threonine, Tryptophan, Isoleucine, Methionine, Histidine, Phenylalanine, Lysine, Leucine.

  • (Mnemonic: PVT-TIM-HALL)

2. Non-essential AA
(Option A)
  • Synthesised in the body
  • Total 6: Arginine, Asparagine, Serine, Proline, Glycine, Glutamine

3. Conditionally-essential AA
(Option C)
  • Non-essential amino acids turn essential if precursors are limited in the body (during stress or illness)
  • Tyrosine, cysteine, glutamine

4. Semi-essential AA
(Option D)
  • Increase requirement during growth (like pregnancy)
  • Arginine, Histidine.

questions.text: Match the following types of food sources with their respective limiting amino acids Food source Amino-acid 1. Corn a. Lysine 2. Wheat b. Methionine 3. Nuts c. Tryptophan 4. Legumes d. Threonine
questions.explanation:
Food item

Limiting amino acid

1. Corn/ Maize
  • Tryptophan & lysine (most common)
  • Tryptophan is a precursor of Vitamin B3 (niacin), hence its deficiency can lead to Pellagra, a condition characterized by “4 D’s” i.e., dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and in severe cases, death.

2. Cereals (Wheat, Rice)
  • Threonine & lysine
  • Rice has a slightly higher lysine content

3. Nuts
  • Lysine

4. Legumes/Pulses
  • Methionine & Cystine

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the protein efficiency ratio (PER)?

options.label: A
options.text: The ratio of protein to the total energy in a diet

options.label: B
options.text: Measure of protein quality based on weight gain per unit of protein consumed

options.label: C
options.text: The balance of essential amino acids in a protein source

options.label: D
options.text: The proportion of protein retained for growth expressed as the amount of nitrogen absorbed.

questions.correct_answer: B. Measure of protein quality based on weight gain per unit of protein consumed
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Amino Acid Score
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ Amino Acid Score = (mg of each essential amino acid in the test protein​ / mg of the same amino acid in the reference protein) x 100
  • ↳ Amino Acid Score = (mg of each essential amino acid in the test protein​ / mg of the same amino acid in the reference protein) x 100
  • ↳ Biological value (BV) refers to the percentage of protein retained in the body for growth, measured in terms of the amount of nitrogen absorbed. (Option D)
  • ↳ Biological value (BV)
  • ↳ (Option D)
  • ↳ Biological value = (Nitrogen retained / Nitrogen absorbed) x 100
  • ↳ Biological value = (Nitrogen retained / Nitrogen absorbed) x 100

Protein-energy ratio (Option A)

Protein Efficiency Ratio (Option B)
  • Energy from protein in food product/total energy x 100
  • PER > 2.5: Better utilisation and promotes growth (animal protein)
  • PER=0.5-2.5: supports life (vegetable protein)
  • Maximum Protein energy ratio = Fish (80%)
  • Weight gain (g) of test subject/amount of protein consumed(g) x 100
  • Laboratory indicator.
  • Assess how well the protein supports growth.

Qualitative measures of protein

1.Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score (DIAAS)

(Option A)
  • Digestible dietary amino acid mg in 1g of dietary protein/same dietary amino acid mg in 1g of reference protein X 100
  • Ideal digestibility coefficient of a food product
  • Best indicator to measure protein quality

2. Digestibility coefficient
(Option B)
  • Amount of amino acid absorbed / amount of protein ingested.
  • External protein quality indicator of the food product.

3. Net Protein Utilization (NPU)
(Option C)


 
  • Digestibility coefficient (external indicator) x Biological value (internal indicator) / 100
  • Percentage of the ingested nitrogen retained in the body
  • 1 gm protein = 6.25gm nitrogen
  • NPU Indian diet: 50-80

4. Biological Value
  • Nitrogen retained/ Nitrogen absorbed x 100

5. Reference protein

(Option D)
  • It is the standard for measuring other proteins, such as eggs, because it has the highest NPU and contains all essential amino acids.

questions.text: Why is an egg known as a reference protein?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the easiest protein to digest.

options.label: B
options.text: It has the highest protein content per gram.

options.label: C
options.text: It contains all essential amino acids.

options.label: D
options.text: It has the longest shelf life of all proteins.

questions.correct_answer: C. It contains all essential amino acids.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ they provide all the essential amino acids in the right proportions needed by the human body.
  • ↳ Egg Importance Eggs are highly nutritious and rich in protein, essential vitamins, & minerals. They support muscle building, brain health, and overall wellness. Rule of 6 6 grams of protein 6 grams of fat 60 calories per large egg 6 essential vitamins (A, B2, B12, D, E, K) 60 grams average weight Others: 6x5=30 mg Calcium 6x0.25=1.5mg Iron

  • ↳ The Net Protein Utilization (NPU) of eggs is typically around 96% . This means that 96% of the protein absorbed from eggs is retained by the body for growth and maintenance.
  • ↳ 96%
  • ↳ Eggs (Option A) are easy to digest and have high bioavailability, meaning the body can efficiently absorb and utilise the protein; this characteristic alone does not make them a reference protein.
  • ↳ (Option A)
  • ↳ Eggs are a good source of protein, but they do not have the highest protein content per gram compared to other protein-rich foods like certain types of fish or meat. (Option B)
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Eggs have a reasonable shelf life when stored properly, but many other protein sources, such as dried legumes or certain preserved meats, have longer shelf lives. (Option D)
  • ↳ (Option D)

Egg

Importance
  • Eggs are highly nutritious and rich in protein, essential vitamins, & minerals.
  • They support muscle building, brain health, and overall wellness.

Rule of 6
  • 6 grams of protein
  • 6 grams of fat
  • 60 calories per large egg
  • 6 essential vitamins (A, B2, B12, D, E, K)
  • 60 grams average weight

Others:

  • 6x5=30 mg Calcium
  • 6x0.25=1.5mg Iron

questions.text: All are true regarding unsaturated fats except?

options.label: A
options.text: Contain one or more double bonds in their fatty acid chains.

options.label: C
options.text: Primarily found in plant-based sources and fish.

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.

questions.correct_answer: D. Increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.
questions.explanation:
Saturated Fats
  • Fatty acid chains have no double bonds, making them solid at room temperature.
  • Predominantly found in animal products such as meat, dairy, and eggs, as well as some plant-based oils like coconut oil and palm oil.
  • Consuming high amounts is associated with increasing levels of LDL cholesterol (bad cholesterol) in the blood, which can raise the risk of cardiovascular diseases such as heart disease and stroke.

Unsaturated Fats
  • Contain one or more double bonds in their fatty acid chains, which makes them usually liquid at room temperature. (Option A and B)
  • Primarily found in plant-based sources such as oils, nuts, and seeds, as well as in fish. (Option C)
  • Considered healthier for consumption as they Improve blood cholesterol levels, reduce inflammation, and lower the risk of cardiovascular disease. (Option D)
  • Types:
    • Monounsaturated fats: single, double bond.
    • Polyunsaturated fats: Multiple double bonds; includes Omega-3 and Omega-6

Trans Fats
  • Industrially produced fats are found in partially hydrogenated oils.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding the reference Indian man and woman? Statements: The reference Indian man is defined as having a body weight of 60 kg and a height of 170 cm. The reference Indian woman is defined as having a body weight of 55 kg and a height of 162 cm. The reference Age range of 19- 29 years is considered The reference Indian BMI ( Woman > Man ) The reference Indian man typically has a waist circumference of 90 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dietary fiber are true? Promotes satiety but has no role in reducing blood glucose Acts as bile acid sequestrants in the small intestine The recommended daily intake is approximately 60 grams Excessive fibre intake can lead to micronutrient malabsorption Bowel irritation can only occur if the daily intake reaches 80 grams
